too, I must needs say; with fine dark eyes and a fresh colour.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Damn his colour! tell me his business.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: So he axed for my Lady, and would not tell me what he wanted: I came with her, however, but she no sooner set eyes on him than she sent me out; which argufy'd no good, you'll say; and, before I could possibly come back, though I ran as fast as ever my legs could carry me, he was gone, and she writing and crying for dear life;—but that was no news, so I did not mind it: and, when she gave me leave to go to the play, thought no more harm than the child unborn.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: It must be a scheme beyond all doubt, and I am the dupe of a dissembling, ungrateful—oh Ce∣cilia! (throws himself in a chair)

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: (Softening her voice and setting her dress) If I was as you, Sir, I would not fret about her:—there is not a lady in the land would slight a gentleman so handsome and sweet temper'd—I scorns to flatter, for my part.—Inferials must'nt direct their betters: but, had I been in my Lady's place, a King upon his throne would not have tempted me.—Handsome him that handsome does, say I; and I am sure you did handsome by her; for, if she could have eat gold, she might have had it.—He might take some notice truly

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: (Starting up) Where was she writing?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: In the little drawing-room, Sir.

This ridiculous love turns peoples brains, I think.—I am sure, I said enough to open his eyes:—but, maybe, I don't look so handsome, because I am not so fine.—Hey,—a thought strikes me! my Lady is gone, that's plain.—Back she will not come, is as plain. (Gathers together Cecilia's elegant clothes.) I'll put on these, and he'll think she gave 'em to me:—then he may find out, I am as pretty as she: if not—he and I are of very different opinions. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Cruel, ungrateful, barbarous girl!—to forsake me in the very moment I was resolving to sa∣crifice ev'ry thing to her!—but 'tis just.—First dupes to the arts of man, the pupil soon knows how to foil him at his own weapons.—Perhaps the discov'ry is fortunate. In a short time, I must have borne the whole disgrace of her ill conduct, and my father's resent∣ment had the bitterest aggravation.—But, is she in∣deed gone? and will continual to-morrows come, without one hope to render them welcome?

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Villain! where's your Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: 'Las a deazy, how can I tell, zur?

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Where are all your fellows?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Abroad, meaking halliday.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: When did you go out? who gave you leave?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: My Leady, her own zelf; and I'll tell you how 'tware.—After dinner I geed her a noate; and, when zhe had red un, zhe axed me if zo be as how I ever zeed the lions? zoa I told her noa; nor nomour I never did.—Zoa zhe geed me half a crown, and bid me goa and make myself happy. I thought it ware desprate koind of her; zoa I went and zeed the huge creturs; and ater, only stop'd a bit to peap at the moniment, and hay my fortin tould by Conj'rer in the Old Bailey; and aw zaid—

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: What the devil does it signify to me what he said?—Hark'e, sir, I see in your face you know more of your mistress?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Dang it, then my feace do lye hugely!

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Tell me the whole truth villain! or I'll stab you to the heart this instant. (Draws his sword.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: (kneels) I wull, zur, indead I wull: doan't ye terrify me zo! I do forget ev'ry thing in the whole world.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Be sincere, and depend on my rewarding you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Why, I wish I meay die this maument, if conj'rer did not zeay I should lose my pleace! nay, aw do verily think aw zaid zomething o'my being put in fear o' my loife. Loard knaws, I little thought how zoon his woords would come to pass.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Will you dally?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Zoa, as I zaid, zur, when I com'd huome again, I found all the duors aupen, and not a zoul to be zeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: (aside) This fellow can never mean to impose on me, and I must think this a plann'd affair'—While I was in the country, Jacob, did your mistress see much company?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Cuompany?—noa, not to speak of,—not gentlewomen.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Gentlewomen? blockhead! why had she any male visitors?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Anan!

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: I must brain thee at last, booby! Did any men come to see her then?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Oh yes, zur, yes—two gentlemen com'd almost ev'ry deay.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: How, two gentlemen? I shall run dis∣tracted! Young, and handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Not auver young, zur, nor auver handsome; but foine.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: So they came almost ev'ry day?—very pretty indeed, Miss Cecilia!—was you never call'd up while they staid?—did they come together or alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Aloane.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: I thought as much; yes, I thought as much. But was you never call'd up, Jacob?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Yes, zur, when one aw um ware here one deay, I ware caal'd up for zomething or other.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Well? why don't you go on? I am on the rack!

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Doan't ye look zo muortal angry then!

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Well, well, I won't, my good fellow!—there's money for thy honesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Well;—there aw ware—

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P:
Speak out freely? you can tell me nothing
worse than I imagine; you won't shock me in the least; not at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Well; there aw ware pleaying on that there music-thing like a cuoffin, and madam ware a zinging to un like any black-bird.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: A music-master—Is that all, booby?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Yes; but t'other, zur—

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Aye, I had forgot;—what of him, good Jacob? what of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: I ware never caall'd up while aw steay'd; zo (I can't but zeay, I had a curosity to knaw what brought he here,) one deay I peap'd thro' the keay∣hole, and zeed un— (titters) —I shall never forget.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Tell me what this instant, or I shall burst with rage and suspense.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Screaping on a leetle viddle, no bigger than my hand; while madam ware a huolding out her quoats, and dancing all round the room zoa— (mimicks the minuet aukwardly.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Why, I believe the impudent bumpkin dares to jest with my misery! and yet I have no other avenue: for the rest, I fear, are knaves, and he seems only a fool—and are these all that came, Jacob?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Noa, there ware one moare, zur; a leetle mon in a black quoat,—but he only com'd now and tan.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: A disguise, no doubt? Yes, yes, they were artful enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P:
And zoa, ater he had done wi' my Leady, aw did shut his self up wi' Bridget; and zoa I axed
her all about un, and zhe zaid as how aw com'd to teach madam to turn themmin great round balls all blue, and red, and yellow, that do stand by the books, and larned she to wroite.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Yes, yes; Mrs. Bridget was in all her se∣crets, I don't doubt. If that fellow in black comes here again, keep him, if you value your life, and send for me. I know not what to do or think, and must renew my search, tho' hopeless of success. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Dang it! but he's in a desprate teaking!—Rabbit me, but I ware muortally afeard aw un too, for aw flourish'd his zword as yeazy as I could a cud∣gel:—and I do think conj'urer might as well ha tuold me madam would ha' run away, while aw ware about it, and then I moight ha' run away furst. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: At length I have gained entrance into the house of shame, which now, alas! contains my dar∣ling Cecilia,—plung'd in vice, and lost to every sen∣timent, I spent so many anxious years in implanting. This does not seem to be the abode of pleasure, nor have I met a single being.

DIV2.STAGE: Woodville entering behind, sees Grey, and, drawing his sword, flies at and seizes him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Ha! a man! and in black, as Jacob said! Villain, this moment is your last.

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: (turning suddenly upon him) Yes, young se∣ducer, add to the daughter's ruin the father's murder! Stab my heart, as you already have my happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Alas, was this her visitor? I dare not speak to him!

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: Embosomed by affluence, exalted by title, peace still shall be far from thy heart; for thou, with the worst kind of avarice, hast by specious pretences wrested from poverty its last dear possession,—virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Plerced to the soul, as I am by your re∣proaches, I dare appeal to Cecilia herself for a testi∣mony of my contrition! How shall I convince you?

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: Hardly by a life of repentance. But I de∣base myself to exchange a word with you. Give me back my Cecilia!—Ruin'd as she is, I yet would re∣cover her:—give her back then to a father you first taught her to fear, and an habitation, too humble for any but the good to be happy in.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Alas, Sir! can you trifle with my misery? do you give her back to the wretch who cannot survive her loss!—let me owe her hand to your bounty, tho' her heart to her own!—did you know what this elope∣ment of her's has cost me—

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: Oh, most accomplish'd villain!—but think not to dupe me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Who but you can have robb'd me of her since morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: Shallow artifice!

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Hear me, Sir! and even believe me, when I solemnly swear I have deeply repented my crime, and offer'd her all the reparation in my power;—but, since then—

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: What since then?

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Either by your means, or some other, she has fled!

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: Impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Tis too true, by heav'n!

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: Perhaps, while you are thus ingeniously de∣luding me, she indeed flies.—Study some other de∣ception, while I examine the whole house, for no∣thing else can convince me. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodville
SP.P: Surely this injur'd venerable man was sent by heav'n to complete my misfortunes!—my passions subside, but only into a vague horror and despondency, even more dreadful:—if with rash hands she has shorten'd her days, what remains of mine will be, indeed, all her father predicts! (walking by the toilette) ha, a letter!

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: A total loneliness in the house!

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Now, sir, be convinced!—I have just found a letter from her.

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: This cannot be the invention of a moment:—let me read it—it is, indeed, her hand. (Opens, and reads it)

LETTER.P: Receive this as my last farewel.—Providence has unexpectedly sent me a friend, whose protec∣tion I dare accept; and time may perhaps subdue a passion, which seems interwoven with my being.—forget me, I intreat; and seek that happiness with another, I can never hope to bestow or partake.—Consoled only by reflecting, that the grief, my error occasions, is inferior to that I should have felt, had I, by an ungenerous use of my power, made you, in turn, my victim.—Once more, adieu!—all search will certainly be fruitless.

POSTSCRIPT.P: P. S. In the cabinet you will find your valu∣able presents; and the key is in a dressing-box.

DIV2.STAGE: (Woodville snatches the letter, and bursts into tears)

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: Cecilia! I may say, with tears of joy, thou art, indeed, my daughter! more dear (if possible) than ever! a daughter monarchs might contend for, though thy weak father abjures thee!—may the friend you have found have a heart but like your own! for you, young man!—but I leave you to your anguish; the loss of such a woman is a sufficient punishment.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Stay, sir! (rises) by your holy profession, I conjure you, stay!—plunge me not into total de∣spair!—though without a clue to her asylum, I would fain believe my heart will lead me to it; and let me then hope you will bestow her on me?

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: There is a something in your manner, young gentleman, that affects me;—I have been young, wild, and extravagant myself; and, what is more strange, have not forgot I was so: my own experience proves reformation possible; act up to her, and atone your error.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: I will endeavour it, sir! and, oh could those who yet but waver, feel what has passed in my heart, during the last hour, who would dare to de∣viate? Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT IV.
DIV2.STAGE: Bridget dressed in Cecilia's Clothes, mixed with every thing vulgar and tawdry.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: SO,—I am ready against our gentleman comes.—Deuce on him to run away last night, the moment I was drest—and with an inferial fellow too!—Lard, how can people of quality demean them∣selves by keeping company with inferials!—however, one thing I am sure of, he's too much on the fidgets to stay long away from our house; and, in the mean while, I can entertain myself extremely well. (Sits down to the toilette)

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: (Without) I tell ye, my leady's not at huome.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: I tell you, I won't take your word for it;—so come, my Lord, and see.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Heyday, my Lord!—what's the news now, I wonder?

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lord Glenmore and the Governor; both stop short.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Oh, I thought madam had learnt enough of the ton to lye by proxy.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Dear heart!—I am all of a twitteration!—who can these be?—that's my Lord, for certain!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: The vulgarity of the wench is astonish∣ing!

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: —Um—why, a little gawky, or so,—there's no denying it.— (aside) Here's a pretty discovery, now, after all my projects!—thank fortune, the se∣cret is yet my own though.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: (Advancing to her) I ought to beg your excuse, madam, for so abrupt an intrusion; but the opportunity and so fair a temptation will, I flatter myself, be a sufficient apology.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: (aside) He takes me for my lady, that's a sure thing!—oh, this is charming!—you need not make no 'poligy's, my Lord;—inferials never knows how to suspect people of quality; but I understands good breeding better.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: (aside) Why, what a Barn-door Mawkin it is! your politeness, madam, can only be equalled by your beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Dear heart, my Lord, you flatter me!—won't you please to sit?— (waits affectedly 'till they consent to seat themselves)

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: (to the Governor) Surely, by using my title, she knows me!

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Zounds, I have a great mind to make her know me!—od, I shall never be able to contain.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: I was afraid, madam, I should prove an unwelcome guest;—but beauty, like yours—

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P:
Does your Lordship think I so very hand∣some,
then?—Lord, how lucky was my dressing my∣self!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: (Aside) Affected ideot!—I was afraid, Madam, too of meeting Woodville here— (aside) I know not what to say to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: He has not been here this morning; but, if he had, he knows better than to ax ater my company, I do assure you, my—Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: I have been told he intends marrying you; what a pity to monopolize such merit!

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: If he has any such kind intention, 'tis more than I knows of, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: His keeping that wise resolution from you, is some little comfort, however.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: But, I promise ye, I shall make a rare person of quality—for I loves cards, coaches, dancing, and dress, to my very heart;—nothing in the world bet∣ter—but Blindman's Buff. I had some thoughts of taking a trip to Sadler's Wells or Fox Hall, but they don't begin till five o'clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: (Aside) Ha, ha! tho' she can hardly spell out the Ten Commandments, she cou'd break every one with as much ease and impudence, as if she had been bred in the circle of St. James's.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: But, Madam, you know, allowing Woodville willing to marry you, it is not in his power while his father lives, without forfeiting his fortune, the value of which you doubtless understand?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Oh, yes, yes, for sartain, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Who knows too, how far an incensed pa∣rent may carry his resentment!—he might find means to entrap and punish you.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!—he entrap me!—that would be a good jest!—no, no, I have more of the lady of quality than to be so easily caught.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: (mimicking her) He, he, he! that is the only particular in which you have nothing at all of the lady of quality.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: With me you may share a higher rank and larger fortune without those fears—I am of an age.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Yes, one may see that without being a con∣juror—why, will you marry me, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Convince me that you don't love this Woodville, and I know not how far my passion may carry me.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Love him? do you think I know no more of high life than that comes to?—To be sure, he is a sweet pretty man, and all that;—but, as to love,—I loves nobody half so well as myself.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Upon my soul, I believe you; and wish he had the whole benefit of the declaration: [to the Governor] her ingratitude is as shocking as her igno∣rance, and Bridewell too gentle a punishment.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Then build a bridewell large enough to con∣tain the whole sex; for the only diff'rence between her and the rest is,—this Country Mawkin tells what the Town-bred Misses conceal.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Why, Governor! you are as testy as if you had had the care of her education.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: I the care?—zounds, what I say is merely from friendship to your Lordship.—I hate to see you deceive yourself.— (Aside) Surely he can never suspect! (Bridget is employ'd in cramming trinkets from the dres∣sing-table into her pockets.)

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Now I am ready to go, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Reflect, Madam!—it would hurt me to have you say I deceiv'd you—if you should repent—I am much afraid you will—

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: What, whn I am a Lady?—oh, I'll ven∣ture that, and attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: (roughly snatching her other hand) To where you little dream of, you vain, affected, presuming, ignorant baggage!

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Hey-day!—my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Appeal not to me, base woman!—know, I am the father of that poor dupe, Woodville.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Dear heart! be ye indeed?—what will be∣come of me then?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: And, as a moderate punishment for your hypocrisy, ambition, and ingratitude, sentence you to be shut up for life in a monastery.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Oh Lord! among monsters?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: No, Ignoramus! no;—among Nuns:—tho' they are but monsters in human nature either.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: What, where they'll cut off my hair, and make me wear sackcloth next to my skin?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Yes, if they leave you any skin at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Oh dear, dear, dear! (sobs and groans) upon my bended knees, I do beg you won't send me there!—why I shall go mallancholly—I shall make away with myself for certain; and my ghost will appear to you all in white!

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: All in black, I rather think; for the devil a speck of white is there in your whole composition.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Your conduct, wretch! justifies a severer sentence—to seduce him from his duty, was crime enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Who, I seduce him? I did not, my Lord—indeed I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Have you not own'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: No, indeed, no; that I wish'd to take my Lady's place, I believe I did own:—

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! very prettily devis'd, faith, for a young beginner!—come, come, (chucking her under the chin) we must give you credit for this, Miss—your Lady? ha, ha,—ha!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Shallow subterfuge! Enter Vane and the Slaves. Vane, is all ready?—seize this woman, and observe my orders!

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Ah dear heart! I shall die away if the blacks do but touch me—indeed you do mistake!—I be no Lady—I be only Bridget.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: I would give ten thousand pounds that you were only Bridget, you artful puss!—Zounds, tho' I could one moment strangle the pug's face in her own necklace, yet the next I can hardly prevail on myself to punish her—what the devil had I now to do in Eng∣land? or what the devil had I ever to do in Wales?—Phew! I could dethrone fifty Nabobs without half the fatigue and anxiety of this moment.—Take her away, however! and let us try how Miss likes riding out in her own coach.

DIV2.STAGE: Vane and the Slaves seize her; she screams out, and catches Lord Glenmore's coat, falling on her knees.—Jacob enters, her back to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Why, what a dickens be ye all at here?—Zoa, what's my Leady there?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: See there now,—Oh the artful Jezebel!

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Oh, Jacob! Why don't ye see I am Brid∣get?—Pray satisfy my Lord here.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Why, be ye Bridget?—Never trust me else!

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Here a fool of t'other sex now, can hardly take a hint though so plainly given him!—Thanks to the natural difference, for art is nature in woman.— (L. Glen. draws him aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Auh Bridget, Bridget! Where didst thee get thee sum foine claws?—Noa, noa, as thee'st brew'd thee meayst beake.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Oh, do ye take pity on me!—Why they be going to carry me to some outlandish place, and make a nun of me!

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: A nun? what's that? any thing Christin? well, if I do spake to um, will ye hae me?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Oh, yes, yes, yes!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Brother! I shall leave you to the com∣pletion of this affair; I am sick to the soul of the gawky—

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Yes, yes; I don't doubt it,—I don't doubt it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: (To Vane.) Convey her to my house, and lock her up in one of the lofts over the stables;—go the backway, and even the family need know nothing of the matter. The Chaplain will provide a licence, and be ready—Courage, my lad, and depend upon my gratitude! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Will you take her, or no?—I shall never be able to stifle my agitation; and burst with rage if I shew it.—

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Why, zure, zure, ye won't carr' away our Bridget?

SP.SPEAKER: Vane.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Oh, she has beat her meaning into thy thick scull a last?—Pr'ythee, keep thy block-head out of my way, if thou mean'st to keep it on thy own shoulders.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Why, be ye in arnest then? dear heart alive! why this is cousin Bridget!

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Only send for Mr. Woodville?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Prettily devis'd again! ha, ha, ha! dost think, my little dear! we have lived three times as long as your Ladyship to learn a quarter as much?—Send for Mr. Woodville, hey?—No, no; you won't find us quite so simple.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Oh doan't ye, doan't ye, carr' off zhe, or if ye wull, do pray take I.

SP.SPEAKER: Vane.
SP.P: Yes, you would be a choice piece of lum∣ber truly.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Drag her away this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Oh dear, oh dear! to be hanged at last for another's crime is all that vexes me.

DIV2.STAGE: They carry her off, Governor follows.
Cecilia enters, and sits down to embroidery.
DIV2.P: How fond, how weak, how ungrateful, are out hearts!—mine still will presumptuously fancy this house its home, and ally itself to ev'ry one to whom Woodville is dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Oh heaven's, my Lord!—how unlucky!—if I go, he may find the Captain with Miss Morti∣mer.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: You see, madam, you have only to re∣tire to engage us to pursue you, even to rudeness.—But, tell me, can it be your own choice to punish us so far as to prefer solitude to our society?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: I know myself too well, my Lord, to receive distinctions of which I am unworthy;—yet think not, therefore, I fail in respect.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: But, is that charming bosom susceptible of nothing beyond respect? why is it capable of in∣spiring a passion it cannot participate?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Your goodness, my Lord—my profound ve∣neration, will always attend you—but, the more ge∣nerously you are inclined to forget what is due to your∣self, the more strongly it is impressed on my memory.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Were what you say true, the bounties of nature atone amply to you for the parsimony of for∣tune; nor would your want of every other advantage lessen your merit, or my sense of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: (aside) Had he thought thus a few months since, how happy had I now been!—Your approba∣tion at once flatters and serves me, by justifying Miss Mortimer's protection of me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Her partiality for you, does her more ho∣nour, than it can ever do you advantage. But, you must tell me, how she gain'd first the happiness of knowing you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: My—my Lord, by a misfortune so touching—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Nay, I would not distress you neither; yet, I own, madam, I wish to make a proposal worth a serious answer; but ought first to know, why you affect a mystery? Tell me then, my dear, ev'ry inci∣dent of your life, and I will raise you to a title, I may without vanity say, many have aspired to!

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: You oppress my very soul, my Lord! But, alas! unconquerable obstacles deprive me for ever of that title. Neither would I obtain it by alienating such a son from such a father.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Put him entirely out of the question; the meanness of his conduct acquits me to myself. Do you know, madam, he has resolved to marry a creature of low birth, illiterate, vulgar, and impu∣dent? and, to complete her perfections, she has been his mistress at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Surely he knows, and purposely shocks me thus. (Aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: But your integrity doesn't render you less amiable in my eyes; it greatly enhances ev'ry other merit. As to his wretch, I have her in my power, and shall make her dearly repent.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Then I am lost indeed! (aside) You have, my Lord; tho' I know not how, discovered.— (Rises in confusion.)

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: (rises, taking snuff, without looking at her) Oh, nothing more easy, madam; I had him carefully traced to her house; and, during his absence, took servants and forced her away.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: (aside) That, however, cannot be me; every word seems to add to a mystery I dare not enquire into.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: But why waste one precious moment on such an animal? what are these unconquerable obsta∣cles?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Spare me, my Lord; your indulgence indu∣ces me to try again to soften your resolutions respecting your son: deprived of the weak, the guilty, the mise∣rable wretch you justly condemn, a little time will (no doubt) incline him to his duty. I should have your pardon to solicit, my Lord, but that your own openness authorizes mine.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: But, can you, who so powerfully plead the cause of another, be deaf to the sighs of a man who adores you? who offers you a rank—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Be satisfied, my Lord, with knowing I have all that esteem your merit claims; which influences me beyond every casual advantage.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: But, madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Alas, my Lord!— (bursts into tears aside) —Be silent, if possible, both pride and virtue. I have de∣served, and will submit to it—yet surely the bitterness of this moment expiates all past offences. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Amiable creature! what an amazing ele∣gance of mind and person! Tears were her only an∣swers to my questions, and blushes to my looks: yet these only heighten a curiosity they have softened into love. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: No intelligence of my Cecilia yet!—were I only assured of her safety, it would be some conso∣lation.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Zur, Zur!—I do meake so bowld as to ax to spake to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Jacob! my honest fellow, the very sight of thee revives my hopes, and sets my heart in motion!—well, what's the news?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Zurprizing news indeed, zur!—Loord, I thought I should never meat wi'ye;—I com'd to your lodgings twice, and ye warn't up.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Up! 'sdeath, you ignorant Booby! why didn't you order them to rouse me that moment?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Loord, zur! why, your gentleman (as they do caal un) were so terrable foine, I ware afeard of affronting un!

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Plague on the stupidity of both, say I!—But what's all this to the purpose? the news? the news?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Las-adeazy! mourtal bad news, indeed!—

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: You tedious blockhead! is your lady re∣turn'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Noa, Zur. (Shaking his head very mourn∣fully.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: (aside) The horrid forebodings of my heart re∣cur; yet, surely she could not be so desperate!—shocking as the suspense is, I more dread the certainty.—Speak, however, my good fellow! (Jacob wipes his eyes) —I shall ever value your sensibility.—Tell me, then, the simple truth, whatever it may be?—

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: I wull, Zur, I wull.—There has com'd two foine gentleman, wi zwords by their zides, just for all the world like yourn.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Well, and what did these gentleman say?

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Why, they went up stears, willy nilly, and carr'd off—our Bridget. (Bursts out a crying.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: You impudent, ignorant clown! I'll give you cause for your tears. (Shakes him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Loord! Loord!—do ye ha a little Christin commiseration—well, if I ever do coume nigh ye a∣gain, I do wish ye may break every buone in my zkin.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: (Walking about in a rage) To insult me with your own paltry love affairs! these great and mighty gentlemen were only constables I dare swear, and your fears converted their staves to swords.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Ay, but that a'nt the worst nither. I do verily think my turn wull cuome next;—cant zleep n my bed for thinking on't, nor enjoy a meal's meat:—zo, except you do bring your zword, and coume and live in our houze, I wull guo out on't, that's a zure thing; for I had rather sceare craws at a graat a deay all my loife long, than bide there to be so terrified.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Sceare craws truly? why, the craws, will sceare you, ye hen-hearted puppy!—there, teake that, (gives him money) and guo huome, or to the devil, so you never fall in my way again.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Zome faulk that I do knaw wull zee the black gentleman first, 'tis my belief—zoa I had best keep out o his woiy too.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Woodville, what's the matter? why you will raise the neighbourhood.

SP.SPEAKER: Jac.
SP.P: Here's a peaper housemaid do zend you, wi her humble duty; but, if zo be it do put ye in ano∣ther desperate teaking, I do huope ye wull zend for zhe to beat, and not I.—Loord! Loord! what wull becuome of me in this woide world of London! (Ex∣it Jacob.)

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! he is a choice fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: A heart, oppressed with its own feelings, fears ev'ry thing. I have hardly courage to open a letter without an address.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Come, come, give it me then?—hey, what? confusion!—was ever any thing so unlucky? (at∣tempts to tear it.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: (snatches it from him) Ha! it is important then?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Why will you invent torments for yourself? (Aside) —My own letter by ev'ry thing careless—here's a stroke—

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: (reads in a broken voice and manner) Wood∣ville on the brink of marriage—you will be disen∣gaged—a nobleman—(damnation!)—heart and fortune at her feet —(I'll let his soul out there) hell and furies!—but I will find him, if money—never will I close my eyes till—Oh Cecilia— (throws himself into a seat.)

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: This is the most unforeseen—I know not what to say to him—prythee, Woodville! do not sa∣crifice so many reasonable presumptions in her favour, to a paper that may be a forgery, for aught you know!

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Oh Charles! that I could think so!—but I have seen the villain's execrable hand somewhere! Did you never see the hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Um—I can't but own I have,—what the devil shall I say to him— Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Woodville, my dear boy! I am come to have a little talk with thee.—Charles! don't run away!—you are in all your cousin's secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: What should possess this tiresome mortal to come here?—I should have waited on you, in half an hour, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Ay, and that's what I wanted to avoid:—The more I talk to your father, Frank, the more I find him fixed on the match with his Miss Mortimer! Nay, he tells me, he will have you married this very day.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: That's mighty probable, in the humour I am in.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Ah, Frank! the girl I offer thee—

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Is no more agreeable to me than her you despise.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: How do you know that, peppercorn?—how do you know that?—od, I could tell you—

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: And, to tell you my full mind. Sir, I had rather make myself a wretch to gratify my father, than any other man.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P:
Od! thou art so obstinate, boy, there's no disliking thee.— (Aside) I don't see why I am obliged
to know his Miss is my daughter—I have a great mind to own what we have done with her; and, if he will marry, e'en take care nobody hinders him! then, trump up a farce about forgiving them;—and yet, it goes against my conscience to punish the puppy for life, though he has punished me pretty sufficiently, by the Lord Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I don't like this affair at all, and tremble for my Sophia, when I see this odd soul so inveterate against her.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: (to Woodville) Well, my lad! do you know I am as deep in all your secrets as your favourite valet de chambre?

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: I don't understand you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Pho, pho, pho! keep that face till I shew thee one as solemn as my Lord's. Why should not you please yourself, and marry your Miss, instead of your father's?

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: Astonishing!

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Od, if you turn out the honest fellow I take you for, I know a pretty round sum, an onion and a black coat may one day or other entitle you to; so never mind Lord Gravity's resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: I act from better motives, Sir, and were unworthy your wealth could it tempt me to disobey the best of fathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P:
(passionately) Why then, marry Miss Morti∣mer, and oblige him: take a back seat in your own coach, get a family of pale-faced brats, born with ostrich-feathers on their heads; and hate away a long life with all due decorum!—Zounds, here's a fellow
more whimsical than—even myself.—Yesterday you would have the puss spite of ev'ry body; but, you no sooner find it in your power to oblige your bestfriend, by humouring your inclinations, than, lo! you are taken with a most violent sit of duty and submission!—Od, you don't know what you have lost by it!—but, since you are bent on crossing me, I'll cross you, and once for all too.—My secret shall henceforth be as impenetrable as the philosopher's stone.—Ay, stare as you please, I'll give you more years than you have yet seen days to guess it in. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: What this uncle of ours can mean is quite beyond my guess!

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: What signifies seeking to expound by rea∣son, actions in which it had no share?—his brain is indubitably touched!—but Cecilia lies heavy on my heart, and excludes ev'ry other thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Time may explain the secret of that letter, which, I will lay my life, she despises:—a woman who did not, would have kept it from your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: That's true, indeed!—if I wrong her, and this was but an insult,—there is a noble sincerity in her own letter which sets suspicion at defiance.—If he stumbled on one word of truth during this visit, the crisis of my fate approaches.—Oh, wherever thou art, if the exalted being I will still hope my Cecilia, thou shalt I know I have at least deserv'd thee! Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT V.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, A mean Room; Boots, Bridles, &c. hang∣ing all round.
Bridget fitting very mournfully, her fine Clothes in great Disorder;—a Table by her, with a small Roll, a Glass of Water, an old dog's-ear'd Book, and a Bit of Looking-glass.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: DEAR heart! dear heart! what a miser∣able time have I pass'd! and, where I be to pass my whole life, my Lord here only knows!—I have not much stomach indeed;—neither have I much break∣fast. (Eats a bit of Bread and bursts into tears.)

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Had I more sins to answer for than a college of Jesuits, I surely expiate them all, by going through a purgatory in this life beyond what they have in∣vented for the other.—This vulgar Maux of mine haunts my imagination, in ev'ry shape but that I hoped to see her in;—I dare hardly trust myself to speak to her!—od, I would not have the extirpation of the whole female sex depend upon my casting-vote while I am in this humor.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Mercy on me! here's that cross old gentle∣man again! what will become of me?—do, pray, strange sir! be so generous as to tell me what is next to be done with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Why, just whatever I please, you audacious baggage!— (Aside) od, now I think on't, I have a great mind to try a few soft words, and dive into all the secrets of the little ignoramus.—Come, sup∣pose I had a mind to grant you your freedom, how would you requite me?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Dear heart! why, I'd love you for ever and ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: 'dzounds, that's a favor I could very readily dispense with;—and yet 'tis natural to the poor wench:—ah! if thou had'st been a good girl, thou hadst been a happy one.—Hark'ye, miss! confess all your sins, that's the only way to escape, I promise you! and, if you conceal the least, I'll—od, I don't know what I'll do to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: I will; I will, sir, indeed, as I hope to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Married, you slut! bad as that is, it's too good for you:—come, tell me all your adventures?—describe the behaviour of the young villain who seduced you;—where did you see him first?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Ugh, ugh,—At church, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: At church, quotha?—a pretty place to commence an intrigue in!—and how long was it be∣fore you came to this admirable agreement?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Umh?—why—Sunday was Midsummer-eve,—and Sunday ater was madam's wedding-day,—and Monday was our fair, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Oh, curse your long histories!—and, what then said Woodville?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Oh Lord, nothing at all—why, it warn't he.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: No.— (ready to burst with passion) Who, who, who? tell me that, and quite distract me!

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Timothy Hobbs, Squire's gardiner.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: An absolute clown— (walks about half groaning with rage and disappointment) who, oh! who would be a father?—I could laugh,—cry,—die,—with shame and anger!—since the man, who corrupted, left her only one virtue, would he had depriv'd her of that too!—oh, that she had but skill enough to lye well!

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Whether I can or no, I'll never speak truth again, that's a sure thing!—what do I get by it, or any poor souls of the female kind?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: I am incapable of thinking;—ev'ry plan, ev'ry resource thus overturn'd;—I must be wiser than all the world?—This fool's head of mine must take to teaching truly! as if I could eradicate the stamp of nature, or regulate the senses, by any thing but reason—don't pipe, baggage! to me;—you all can do that, when too late:—when I have considered whether I shall hang myself or not, I'll let you know whether I shall tuck you up along with me, you little wretch, you! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Well, sure I have at last guess'd where I am shut up!—it must be Bedlam; for the old gentleman is out of his mind, that's a sure thing!

SP.SPEAKER: Van.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! my future father-in-law seems to have got a quietus of my intended; and, faith, so wou'd any man who was not in love with a certain forty thousand;—to be sure, in plain English, she is a glorious mawkin!— (to her) —well, madam, how are you pleas'd with your present mode of living?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Living, do you call it?—I think, 'tis only starving.—Why, I shall eat my way thro' the walls very shortly.

SP.SPEAKER: Van.
SP.P: Faith, Miss, they use you but so so, that's the truth on't; and I must repeat, even to your face, what I said to my Lord, that your youth, beauty, and accomplishments, deserve a better fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Dear heart! Bedlam, did I say, I was in! why, I never knew a more sensibler, genteeler, prettier sort of a man in my life. (aside) —I am sure, Sir, if I was to study seven years, I shou'd never know what I have done to discommode them, not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Van.
SP.P: Oh Lard, my dear! only what is done ev'ry day by half your sex without punishment—however, you are to suffer for all, it seems?—you see your fare for life!—a dungeon, coarse rags, and the same hand∣some allowance of bread and water twice a day.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Oh, dear me!—why, I shall be an otomy in a week!

SP.SPEAKER: Van.
SP.P: And an old black to guard you, more sulky and hideous, than those in the Arabian Night's Enter∣tainments.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Why, sure they will let you come and see me, Sir? I shall certainly swound away, ev'ry time I look at the nasty old black.

SP.SPEAKER: Van.
SP.P: This is the last time your dungeon (which your presence renders a palace to me) will ever be open to one visitor—unless—unless—I cou'd contrive—but no, it would be my ruin:—yet who woud'nt venture something for such a charming creature? you could endear even ruin.—Tell me, then, what reward you would bestow on a man who ventur'd all to give you freedom?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Nay, I don't know; you're such a dear sweet kind soul, I shan't stand with you for a trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Van.
SP.P: Ahey! Miss will be as much too com∣plying in a minute.—Well, then, my dear! I must marry you, or you will still be in the power of your enemies.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Hey?—what? do I hear rightly? marry me?— (aside) —why, this will be the luckiest day's work I ever did!—nay, Sir, if you should be so generous, I hope I shall live to make you amends!

SP.SPEAKER: Van.
SP.P: (aside) The only amends you can make me, is by dying—and now, my dear! I will own to you, I have the license in my pocket; and my Lord, as eager as myself.—Our chaplain will do us the favour with more expedition than he says grace before meat!—Well done, Vane! egad, thy lucky star predomi∣nates!— (Aside—takes her arm.)

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Surely my locking up does end very comi∣cal. Exeunt arm in arm.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Mor.
SP.P: Woodville is now with his father, and both in the decisive mood.—Oh, Charles! as the moment approaches nearer, your influence becomes insensibly less powerful:—the frantic fits of the Governor; the solemn absurdity of my Lord—but, above all, the behaviour of Woodville, hurts and alarms me!—still cautious not to offend his father, he has tried ev'ry way to extort the refusal from me; but, by a pardon∣able equivocation, I left him hopeless, and assured him I should, to the utmost of my power, obey my bene∣factor.—Why, why did you marry one, who could give you nothing but her heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I shall not answer, till you can name me an equivalent—trust to my management, my dear So∣phia.—I still flatter myself, one storm will settle the tenor of our lives—if not; while acquitted to Heav'n, the world, and ourselves, we may struggle with spirit against fortune; and sometimes owe our dearest enjoy∣ments to her fluctuations.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Mor.
SP.P: By sentiments like these you won my very soul; and to retain for ever a heart so invaluable, I have ventur'd the displeasure of my benefactor: but our hearts will not always follow the lead of our rea∣son, nor, when I consider the cause, can I repent the deviation of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Think, if you pity yourself, what you can give to Cecilia; and fortify her mind against too strong a sense of her frailty. For my part, I must watch whatever is going on.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Mor.
SP.P: So, you leave me out of the plot?—well, if it ends happily, I shall be contented; and, like the world, measuring your merit by your success, will declare you a most inimitable schemer.—Adieu!

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Nay, stay a moment!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Mor.
SP.P: Not for the world; for here comes your uncle, with a face more petrifying than Medu∣sa's. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: I have lived fifty eight years, five months, and certain odd days, to find out I am a fool at last; but I will live as many more, before I add the disco∣very that I am a knave too.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: What the devil can he be now hatching?—mischief, I fear?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Dear fortune! let me escape this once un∣discover'd, and I compound for all the rest.—Charles! the news of the house? for the politicks of this family are employment for ev'ry individual in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Bella, horrida bella, Sir!—my Lord is determined to bring his son's duty to an immediate test,— (aside) thanks to his friend's schemes and his mistress's beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P:
What poor malicious wretches are we by na∣ture?—Zounds, if I could not find in my heart to
rejoice at thinking every one here will be as mortified and disappointed as a certain person that shall be nameless.—So, so; here they come, faith, to argue the point in open court.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lord Glenmore followed by Woodville.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Without this proof of your obedience, all you can urge, Sir, is ineffectual.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: While obedience was possible, I never swerv'd, my Lord; but, when you command me to make myself wretched, a superior duty cancels that:—already bound by a voluntary, an everlasting vow, I cannot break it without offending heav'n, nor keep it without offending you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: (aside) What's this? chop'd about again!

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Did you once know the incomparable me∣rits of my love, even your Lordship's prejudices must give way to your reason.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Mere dotage.—But, had she more than any one woman ever yet possess'd, doesn't her conduct equally evince her folly and depravity?

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Cover'd, as I ought to be, with confusion and remorse; I will own she was seduc'd and de∣ceiv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: (aside) Ah, poor boy!—one of the two was woefully deceiv'd sure enough.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Oh, your conscience may be very easy on that account; it could not require much art to de∣ceive such an ideot.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: No, no, my Lord; why paint the devil blacker than he is? not an ideot neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Sir, my father's freedom of speech I must endure;—but yours—

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: You must endure too, young Sir, or I shall bite my tongue off.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: But, my Lord! that dear unhappy girl is no longer a subject of debate,—she evidently proves her merit by her flight.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Would you make a virtue from not do∣ing ill, when it is no longer in your power?—Wood∣ville! I was once weak enough to believe indulgence the surest way of obtaining your duty and esteem.—My eyes are at last opened,—Miss Mortimer is wor∣thy a better husband; but you are her's, or no son of mine.—I solemnly promised this to her dying father, and will acquit myself at all events.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Can you resolve to sacrifice me to a pro∣mise made before we could judge of each other?—You never felt, Sir, the compulsion you practice;—will you dissolve the first band of morality, and see your highly-estimated title end in me? for never will I on these terms continue it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: I almost wish I never had continued it.— (Walks in anger.). I am determined, Woodville! and nothing but Miss Mortimer's refusal can break the match.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: I shall not put that in her power, my Lord? Permit me to tell you, no son was ever more sensible of a father's kindness: but, if I can purchase its continuance only with my honour and my happi∣ness, it would be too dearly bought.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: 'Tis well, sir.—I have listened to you sufficiently. Now hear ME. Know, this worthless wretch, you prefer to your duty, is in my power; nay, in this house.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: (aside) The devil she is! how in the name of ill-luck should he find that out?—my fine scheme entirely blown up, by Jupiter!

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Why play thus upon me, my Lord?—her letter—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: What, has she wrote to you?—that I was not aware of, nor indeed suspected she could write.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: No, not so ignorant as that neither. I or∣der'd she should write too!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: You order'd she should write?—let me tell you, sir, it was wronging my confidence!

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: No, I did not order she should write;—I mean,—I mean,—zounds! I don't know what I mean!

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: So it seems, indeed; since hardly half an hour ago my uncle himself persuaded me to marry my love.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Here's a cursed affair now!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Can this be possible? Let me tell you, Governor, if, presuming upon your wealth, you play a double part in my family—

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P:
Zounds! nobody knows his own part in your family, that I see! and this fellow, too, to teize me, whom I lov'd above all in it Why, I spoke entirely from regard to him. If, since then I have discovered
a bumpkin was beforehand with him in the possession of his miss—

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: If any one, beside yourself, sir, durst tell such a falshood, it would cost a life.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Yes; and, if any one beside myself durst tell me such a truth, it would cost a soul perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: This is more unintelligible than all the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: To end these altercations;—upon your∣self, Woodville, shall depend the fortune of this wretch, to whom you have been so gross a dupe as to justify the imputation of folly. Why, even without knowing me, she ridiculed your passion, and offered to leave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Dare you disbelieve me, sir?—nay, she shall be produced, and obliged to confess her arts;—then blush and obey! Here, Vane! Governor, the keys! Exit.

DIV2.STAGE: Woodville walks behind, in great agitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Now could I find in my heart to make this story into a ballad, as a warning to all meddling pup∣pies; and then hang myself, that it may conclude with a grace. Zounds, he must be endued with su∣pernatural intelligence. Just when I was saying a thousand civil things to myself on my success, to have my mine sprung before my eyes by the enemy; and, instead of serving my friend and myself, become a meer tool to old Gravity's revenge! 'Pshaw! how∣ever, we must make the best of a bad matter.—Woodville, what do'st mean to do, man?

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Let them produce my Cecilia!—then seize, and protect her to the last moment of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: And I will assist you to the last moment of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: My generous cousin! this is indeed friend∣ship.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Not so very generous, if you knew all.

DIV2.STAGE: Re-enter Lord Glenmore and the Governor, with Bridget holding a handkerchief to her eyes, Vane fol∣lowing; Woodville flies and clasps her in his arms; Harcourt takes her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: My love! my life!—do I once again be∣hold thee?—fear nothing!—you here are safe from all the world!—will you not bless me with one look?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: (looking at him and Harcourt with ridiculous distress) oh, dear me!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: I have put it out of your power to mar∣ry, Sir, otherwise you may take her.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Take her!—what poor farce is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Hey-day! more incomprehensibilities.

SP.SPEAKER: Van.
SP.P: Aside Now for the eclaircissement—since, if the Governor doesn't acknowledge her in his first rage and confusion, I may never be able to make him!—I humbly hope, Mr. Woodville will pardon me, if, with her own consent and my Lord's, I this morning married this young lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P:
Zounds, you dog, what's that?—you mar∣ried her?—why, how did you dare—and you
too, my Lord!—what the devil, did you consent to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Vane.
SP.P: Believe me, sir, I didn't then know she was your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: So, it's out, after all:—it's a lye, you dog! you did know she was my daughter;—you all knew it;—you all conspired to torment me!

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! confound your mirth!—as if I had not plagues enough already.—And you have great reason to grin too, my Lord, when you have thrown away my Gawky on your impudent valet.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Who could ever have dreamt of—ha, ha, ha—of finding this your little wonder of the country, brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Nay, my Lord, she's the little wonder of the town, too.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Mighty well,—mighty well,—mighty well; pray, take your whole laugh out, good folks! since this is, positively, the last time of my enter∣taining you in this manner.—A cottage shall hence∣forth be her portion, and a rope mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: If you are my papa, I think you might give some better proof of your kindness;—but I shan't stir;—why, I married on purpose that I might not care for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P:
Why, thou eternal torment!—my original sin!—whose first fault was the greatest frailty of wo∣man; and whose second, her greatest folly! do'st
thou, or the designing knave who has entrapped thee merely for that purpose, imagine my wealth shall ever reward incontinence and ingratitude?—no; go knit stockings to some regiment where he is preferred to be drummer!—warm yourself when the sun shines!—soak ev'ry hard-earn'd crust in your own tears, and repent at leisure. Exit in a rage.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: He to ridicule my mode of education!—but, what is the meaning of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Truly, my Lord, I believe it would be very hard to find any for either my uncle's words or actions!—I am equally at a loss to guess as to Bridget here.

SP.SPEAKER: Vane.
SP.P: Hey, what? Bridget, did you say, sir? why, you little ugly witch! are you really Bridget?

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Why, I told ye so, all along; but you woud'nt believe me?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: Oh dear heart!—I am now as much afeard of my new husband as father.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: For thee, Wench—

SP.SPEAKER: Brid.
SP.P: (Pops upon her knees) Oh, no more locking up, for goodness sake, my Lord!—I be sick enough of passing for a lady: but, if old Scratch ever puts such a trick again in my head, I hope—your Lord∣ship will catch me! that's all. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Vane.
SP.P: I shall run distracted! have I married an—and all for nothing too?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P:
A punishment peculiarly just, as it re∣sults from abusing my confidence.—Hence, Wretch!
nor ever, while you live, appear again in my pre∣sence. Exit Vane, looking furiously after Bridget.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: 'Tis time to return to ourselves. We shall soon come to an eclaircissement, Woodville!—Since you won't marry, I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: My Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: And you shall judge of my choice. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Now for it;—whatever devil diverts him∣self among us to-day, I see he owes my sagacious Lord here a grudge, as well as the rest; and I foresee that his wife and the Governor's daughter will prove equally entertaining.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lord Glenmore leading Cecilia, followed by Miss Mortimer.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: This lady, Sir, I have selected;—a worthy choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: I dream, surely!—that lady your choice?—yours.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Ungrateful son! had such been yours—

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Why, this very Angel is mine, my Ceci∣lia, my first, my only love!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: How!—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord!—you now know the un∣happy object at once of your resentment, contempt, and admiration!—my own misfortunes I had learnt to bear, but those of Woodville overpower me!—I deliver myself up to your justice; content to be ev'ry way his victim, so I am not his ruin.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: But to find you in this house—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Your generous nephew and the amiable Miss Mortimer distinguish'd me with the only asylum could shelter me from your son!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: They distinguished themselves!—Oh, Woodville! did I think an hour ago I could be more angry with you?—How durst you warp a mind so noble?

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: It is a crime my life cannot expiate,—yet, if the sincerest anguish—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: I have one act of justice still in my power;—my prejudice in favour of birth, and even a stronger prejudice, is corrected by this lovely girl:—of her goodness of heart, and greatness of mind, I have had incontestible proofs, and, if I thought you, Frank—

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Yet, stay, my Lord! nor kill me with too much kindness.—Once your generosity might have made me happy, now only miserable.—My reason, my pride, nay even my love, induces me to refuse, as the only way to prove I deserve him!—he has taught me to know the world too late, nor will I re∣tort on him the contempt I have incurr'd:—Mr. Woodville will tell you whether I have not solemnly vow'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Not to accept me without the consent of both fathers; and, if mine consents, what doubt—
Stop that old man! stop that mad parson! stop him!
Nothing shall stop me in pursuit of my— (enters) Ha! she is—she is here indeed! providence has at length directed me to her (runs to Cecilia.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: My father! cover'd with shame let me sink before you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen. and Har.
SP.P: Her father!

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: Rise, my glorious girl! rise purified and for∣given! rise to pity with me the weak minds that know not all thy value, and venerate the noble ones that do.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Hey! is it possible! Grey, is this my—

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; this is your Cecilia, my Cecilia, the object of your avowed rejection and contempt!

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Rejection and contempt! stand out of the way—let me embrace my daughter—let me take her once more to my heart— (runs and embraces her.)

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: His daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Yes, my friends, this is really my daughter—my own Cecilia, as sure as I am an old fool after being a young one, this good girl has a right to call me so by the name of father.—Hasn't she, Grey?—why, my Lord, this is the very parson I told you of!— (taking Cecilia's arm under his) and now, young Sir, what do you say to your uncle's freaks?

SP.SPEAKER: Wood.
SP.P: Say, Sir, that had you ten thousand such I would go through a patriarchal servitude, in hopes of Cecilia's hand for my reward.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: And, had I ten millions of money, and this only girl, thou should'st have her, and that, too, for thy noble freedom.—And what says my Cecilia to her father's first gift?

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Astonishment and pleasure leave me hardly power to say, that a disobedience to you, sir, would only double my fault: nor to worship that Heav'n, which has led me through such a trial to such a re∣ward!—take all I have left myself to give you, Woodville, in my hand— (Woodville kisses first her hand, and then herself)

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: Now, let me die, my darling child! since I have seen thee, once more, innocent and happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: And now, kiss me, my Cecilia!—kiss me!—od, Miss Mortimer shall kiss me too, for loving my poor girl here!—kiss me, all of you, old and young!—men, women and children!—od, I am so overjoy'd, I dread the consequences.—D'ye hear, there?—fetch me a surgeon and a bottle of wine!—I must both empty and fill my veins on this occasion—zooks, I could find in my heart to frisk it merrily in defiance of the gout, and take that cursed vixen be∣low, whoever she is, for my partner!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: Methinks all seem rewarded, but my poor Sophia here? and her protection of Cecilia deserves the highest recompence: but whenever, my dear, you can present me the husband of your choice, I will present him with a fortune fit for my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P:
Protect Cecilia! od! she is a good girl, and a charming girl, and I honour the very tip of her feathers now!—if she could but fancy our Charles,
I'd throw in something pretty on his side, I promise you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Mor.
SP.P: Frankness is the fashion.—What would you say, Sir, and you, my Lord, if I had fan∣cied your Charles so much, as to make him mine already?

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Hey day! more discov'ries! how's this, boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Even so, Sir, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Glen.
SP.P: It completes my satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Gov.
SP.P: Od, brother! who'd have thought you in the right all the while—we'll never separate again, by the Lord Harry! but knock down our Welch friend's old house; and raise him one on the ruins, large enough to contain the whole family of us, where he shall reign sole sov'reign over all our future little Woodvilles and Cecilias.

SP.SPEAKER: Cec.
SP.P: Oppressed with wonder, pleasure, gratitude, I must endeavour to forgive myself, when heav'n thus graciously proves its forgiveness, in allying me to ev'ry human being my heart distinguishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Grey.
SP.P: Yes, my Cecilia, you may believe him, who never gave you a bad lesson, that you are now most truly entitled to esteem; since it requires a far greater exertion to stop your course down the hill of vice, than to toil slowly up toward virtue.
